Hi Thomas, essentially what you are proposing is just an alternative form=
 of historical marking.  Whether you match up the nodes or match up the con=
nections, either way the numbers assigned to those nodes or connections mus=
t come from a chronological history of their additions.  The numbers assign=
ed to nodes are also historical markings derived from a counter that increm=
ents every time a new node appears.

In most NEAT implementations, both nod=
es and connections receive markings in this way.  The traditional NEAT algo=
rithm uses the connection markings to match up networks, but the node marki=
ngs could also be used.  In effect, the history is over-specified when you =
have both, but there is no harm in that and it generally is a good idea any=
way to mark both nodes and connections so that we can easily understand whe=
n certain structures (i.e. both nodes and connections) appeared relative to=
 other structures.

Note that there are some philosophical issues that aris=
e if you really tried to use only node markings.  What happens in that case=
 is that it is no longer possible for connections between the same two node=
s in two different individuals to have different markings.  While one might=
 argue that such a connection should always have the same marking, I would =
personally disagree because that is like saying that a protein that arises =
in fish that is used for one purpose is the "same" as a similar protein tha=
t arose independently in humans for an entirely different purpose.  Because=
 the aim of these markings is ultimately to figure out how different indivi=
duals are related, I don't think it's necessarily in our interest to say th=
at such genes are really the "same" when they come from such divergent line=
ages with such incompatible purposes.

In practice, it is likely that the s=
ystem would still work okay in either case, since the most important princi=
ple is just to keep generally similar structures clustered together.  The m=
inutia of slightly differing approaches will not have major (though they ma=
y have minor) impact.

ken
